question.title: Cannot find class after packaging in java
question.body:
I'm trying to make a game in java and made the frame, panel, and keyhandler class located within the same folder. When I include proper package declarations in each of the class files and try to compile or run the program, the classes are unable to locate each other, resulting in compilation errors. However, when I remove the package declarations entirely and place the classes in the default (unnamed) package, everything compiles and runs without any issues.

file directory looks like this:

ProjectEX
----source
      ----Main
      ----GamePanel
      ----KeyHandler

error message

package source;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Dimension;
import java.lang.Thread;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Graphics2D;
import javax.swing.Timer;

public class GamePanel extends JPanel 
{
    final int tileSize=16*3;
    final int screenRow=18;
    final int screenCol=22;
    final int screenHeight=tileSize*screenRow;
    final int screenWidth=tileSize*screenCol;

    int playerX = 100, playerY = 100;
    int speed = 10;
    KeyHandler keyHandler = new KeyHandler();

    public GamePanel() 
    {
        this.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(this.screenWidth, this.screenHeight));
        this.setBackground(Color.WHITE);
        this.setFocusable(true);
        this.addKeyListener(this.keyHandler);
        this.requestFocusInWindow();

        Timer timer = new Timer(16, e -> 
        {
            update();
            repaint();
        });

        timer.start();
    }

    public void update() 
    {
        if (this.keyHandler.up) 
            this.playerY -= this.speed;
        if (this.keyHandler.down) 
            this.playerY += this.speed;
        if (this.keyHandler.left) 
            this.playerX -= this.speed;
        if (this.keyHandler.right) 
            this.playerX += this.speed;
    }

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) 
    {
        super.paintComponent(g);

        Graphics2D g2=(Graphics2D)g;
        g2.setColor(Color.BLACK);
        g2.fillRect(this.playerX, this.playerY, this.tileSize, this.tileSize);
        g2.dispose();
    }
}

package source;
import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;
import java.awt.event.KeyListener;

public class KeyHandler implements KeyListener
{
    public boolean up,down,left,right;

    public KeyHandler(){}

    @Override
    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) 
    {
        int code = e.getKeyCode();

        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_W) up = true;
        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_S) down = true;
        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_A) left = true;
        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_D) right = true;
    }

    @Override
    public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) 
    {
        int code = e.getKeyCode();

        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_W) up = false;
        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_S) down = false;
        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_A) left = false;
        if (code == KeyEvent.VK_D) right = false;
    }

    @Override
    public void keyTyped(KeyEvent e) {}
}

I tried making another folder and packaging it inside that folder and still did the same thing

answers.body:
Your package name source is suspicious.

My guess is that you have not created a folder hierarchy matching your declared package.

By convention, a package name is a reversal of your domain name. Example: If your domain is Acme.com, and your app is PowerApp, then your package is com.acme.powerapp. Your project should have a corresponding hierarchy of nested folders matching the parts of your package name.

  • 📂 com
    • 📂 acme
      • 📂 powerapp
        • 📄 GamePanel.java
        • 📄 KeyHandler.java

See the tutorial by Oracle free-of-cost, Naming a package.

An IDE will help to manage your packages. I recommend using IntelliJ, NetBeans, or Eclipse. For example, see this tutorial on creating packages and .java files in your project using IntelliJ.

You’ve not given enough detail for us to diagnose. I suggest you make a new project, driven by either Maven or Gradle. Use a template from your IDE to generate the project, or use a Maven archetype. Immediately compile, and package into your final artifact. Then gradually bring over parts of your app, do a full compile and packaging as you take small steps in recreating your app.

And study the Swing tutorial too.

question_comments.body: I suspect you may have told your IDE that source is the location of your source code tree. But it’s not—the package directory is part of the source code, so the root of your source code tree needs to be ProjectEx.
